awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Broad-Energy Germanium Detector at Western Washington University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made to Western Washington University (WWU) to purchase a broad-energy germanium gamma ray detector to expand research and education programs in environmental science and geology. The earth possesses many naturally occurring radioactive elements that emit gamma radiation. By measuring the quantity and distribution of these elements, researchers can estimate the rates of important processes, such as the burial of sediment and organic carbon, removal of contaminants from seawater, and the mixing and transport of important particulate materials including carbon, metals, and organic contaminants. The instrument will allow students and faculty at WWU to quantify sedimentary processes, characterize past environments, and to assess changes in land use, pollution, and other natural conditions over time. The research community’s interest in the use of our existing gamma detector and our associated expertise has now exceeded our ability to accommodate the demand. The expanded capabilities of this instrument will enable WWU students and faculty to address new environmental problems, take on additional research projects, improve the design of existing projects, and expand our network of collaborators at the global scale. 

The new broad-energy germanium detector (Mirion BE3825) will support the research and teaching programs of eight senior personnel and their associated students at WWU. These users all have research questions that can be addressed using gamma-emitting radionuclides, with applications ranging from bioturbation and sediment accumulation to tribal coastal clam gardens and estuarine carbon burial, to lake paleo-genetics and riparian geomorphological development. While our existing detector is in continuous use measuring low-energy gamma emitters such as Pb-210 and Th-234, the new broad-energy germanium detector will also enable the measurement of higher-energy gamma emitters such as Cs-137, Be-7, Zn-65, and Fe-59, allowing for a much greater number of users, more educational opportunities, and a greater diversity of instrument applications. As a non-PhD granting institution, WWU places a strong emphasis on undergraduate and Masters-level research and education. The new instrument at WWU will be made available not only for faculty-driven research but also for student-led thesis research and class projects to train the next generation of scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this grant, Western Washington University acquired a Broad Energy Germanium Detector to count gamma ray emissions of known wave lengths from naturally occurring elements.  By measuring the quantity and distribution of these elements, researchers can then estimate the rates of important processes, such as the accretion of sediment and organic carbon, removal of contaminants from seawater, and the mixing and transport of important particulate materials including carbon, metals, and organic contaminants.  For example, we can collect a sediment core from a coastal marsh and, with this instrument, estimate rates of sediment accretion.  We can then compare rates of accretion to rates of sea level rise and use that information to predict the resiliency of coastal systems to rising sea levels and to guide the course of restoration and mitigation efforts, if needed. 

The most interesting, and most expensive, part of the detector is the 3000-pound lead shield (see the accompanying figure) used to protect the sample from background, natural gamma ray emissions. When people first see the massive lead shield, they are understandably concerned that it must be there to protect us from some dangerous level of radiation coming from whatever is inside the shield.  In fact, the exact opposite is true, the shield is there to protect the samples within it from us!  The instrument was delivered to us in May of 2022 and, after assembly, siting, calibration, and training, became operational in May of 2023 and has been in use 24/7 ever since. This instrument is particularly impactful because the research community’s interest in the using this gamma detector greatly exceeds our ability to accommodate the demand.  With this detector, we now can take on additional research projects, improve the study design of existing projects (adding more sites or more replicate cores per site), and expand our network of collaborators at the regional and global scale. 

As a non-PhD granting institution, WWU provides research opportunities to both Masters-level graduate students and undergraduate students. Graduate programs in Environmental Science and Geology departments are structured around student-led thesis research, providing ample opportunity for student use of the proposed instrument for primary research. Undergraduate student research may occur at a number of levels, including independent studies and senior thesis projects, research assistantships as part of faculty or graduate student projects, and regular lab courses. We anticipate undergraduate students using the proposed instrument at each of these levels. Training can be provided to students on instrument use and data interpretation by faculty or lab staff. With the instrument relatively easy to use, it does not require substantial upfront training time therefore making it accessible for both short-term and long-term student projects. For graduate students working on thesis research, the use of the proposed instrument will significantly lower research costs since sending samples to an external lab is cost-prohibitive.
